div.head: The Mūlasarvāstivāda
div.p: Some heirs to Sarvāstivādin lineages, initially clustered around Mathurā and regions to its northwest, claimed primacy among the Sarvāstivādins in calling themselves the Mūlasarvāstivādin, or “Original Sarvāstivādins” (Yao 2007, pp. 246–47). Their vinaya, the Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya (MSV), which was written and recorded in Sanskrit circa the second through the sixth centuries CE, is the longest of all known vinayas. The MSV’s length is due mainly to its “settings” or “narrative introductions” (Tib. gleng gzhi; Skt. nidāna). These “settings” introduce and illustrate the reason for new monastic rules. Many of the protagonists in these settings are anonymous. Some appear repeatedly, like the monk Upananda and the nun Sthūlananda, as personifications of “good” or “bad” monks and nuns. Most distinctively for the MSV, some of these protagonists even feature in lengthy frame stories that culminate in the Buddha explaining the protagonist’s karmic history in what is called an avadāna (Tib. rtogs brjod).

The MSV consists of a “root āgama” (the Prātimokṣā Sūtras for monks and nuns) and four “explanatory āgamas”: (1) The Chapters on Monastic Discipline (Tib. ’dul ba gzhi; Skt. Vinayavastu) (2) The Analysis of the Monks’ and Nuns’ Disciplines (Tib. ’dul ba rnam ’byed; Skt. Vinayavibhaṅga); (3) The Chapter on Minor Matters of Monastic Discipline (Tib. ’dul ba pran tshegs kya gzhi; Skt. Vinayakṣudrakavastu), and (4) The Supplementary Books (Tib. ’dul ba gzhung dam pa and ’dul ba gzhung bla ma; Skt. Uttaragrantha). Large portions of the Sanskrit MSV are still extant. A partial eighth c. Chinese translation by Yijing and a complete ninth c. Tibetan translation are also extant. See Clarke 2015, pp. 73–80.

From an academic perspective, the only reliable means we have of distinguishing the "Mūlasarvāstivādins" from the Sarvāstivādins is their respective vinayas. In fact, the two "schools" seem to (mostly) share in common a sūtra and abhidharma piṭaka. For instance, the Sarvāstivādin Abhidharma is well known and studied but there is no evidence for a separate Mūlasarvāstivādin abhidharma piṭaka. Thus, the "split" is probably best taken as a rhetorical claim rather than a historical fact. In short, the most defensible description of Mūlasarvāstvādin is unfortunately tautological: the Mūlasarvāstivādins are the upholders of the Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya. If citations are needed, Yao (2007) and Clarke (2015) should be mentioned.

Perhaps we should direct the reader to three texts in the Vinaya section of the Tengyur (Toh 4138-4140) where the Buddhist monastic community's split into two and eventually "eighteen" nikāya is recounted. The primary sources are not consistent on the identification of these 18 and their views. Incidentally, scholarship on Mahāyoga tantra has shown that "eighteen" is a generic numerical descriptor, like 84000 or the "10,000 things" in Chinese tradition. In other words, there are many ways to slice up the "eighteen nikāya" so we might want to avoid that rabbit hole, at least as for this glossary entry.

Though included in the Vinaya section of the Tengyur, Toh 4138-4140 are only nominally "vinaya" texts since they are based on abhidharma texts, as reflected in their preoccupation with doctrinal issues (Tib. grub mtha’; Skt. siddhānta).
div.label: Texts:

item.p: Toh 4138 Vasumitra's Samayabhedavyūha cakra or "A Wheel Displaying the Different Traditions" (དབྱིག་གི་བཤེས་གཉེན། གཞུང་ལུགས་ཀྱི་བྱེ་བྲག་བཀོད་པའི་འཁོར་ལོ།, aka གཞུང་ཐ་དད་པ་རིམ་པར་བཀླག་པའི་འཁོར་ལོ།). This is the least informative and complete of the three texts.

Toh 4139 Bhāvya's Nikāyabheda vibhaṅga vyākhyāna or "An Explanation and Analysis of the Eighteen Nikāya" (སློབ་དཔོན་བྷ་བྱ། སྡེ་པ་ཐ་དད་པར་བྱེད་པ་དང་རྣམ་པར་བཤད་པ། སྡེ་པ་བཅི་བརྒྱད་ཀྱི་མིང་དང་རིམ་པ།). This was excerpted from Bhavya's famous Tarkajvālā རྟོག་གེ་འབར་བ།. It is, however, the most complete account of the 18 nikāya in the Tengyur. Unfortunately, it does not mention the Mūlasarvāstivādins.

Toh 4140 Vinītadeva's Samayabhedoparacanacakre nikāyabhedopadeśana saṁgraha or "Compendium of Instructions on the Different Nikāya" from Samayabhedoparacanacakra (སློབ་དཔོན་དུལ་བའི་ལྷ། གཞུང་ཐ་དད་པ་རིམ་པར་བཀླག་པའི་འཁོར་ལོ་ལས་སྡེ་པ་ཐ་དད་པ་བསྟན་པ་བསྡུས་པ་ཞེས་བྱ་བ།). According to its colophon (F.156.a), this text is based on Vasubandhu's Abhidharmakośa.

div.p: Unfortunately, the most accurate description of "Mūlasarvāstvādin" is tautological: the Mūlasarvāstivādins are the upholders of the Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya. Other ways of distinguishing them from other nikāya or "ordination lineages" are recorded in Indic texts, which were included in the Vinaya section of the Tengyur (Toh 4138-4140) but are, in fact, extracts from śāstra. The descriptions they give are not entirely consistent, either. Furthermore, the Mūlasarvāstivādins seem to have shared much of their sūtra and abhidharma texts with the Sarvāstivādins In short, the only reliable means we have of distinguishing the "Mūlasarvāstivādins" from the Sarvāstivādins is by their respective vinayas; the former contains extensive "settings" and avadāna while the latter does not.
